We should all ask our elected representatives what they are doing in light of the CCP challenge, and these officials should have a good response. This is the greatest international challenge facing the free world. It’s time we start acting like it.

But for all the progress, we could still choose to bury our head in the sand about the challenge before us. Open conflict with China is avoidable, if we play our cards right, but competition is inevitable. In fact, it’s already here, and it’s happening on a daily basis.

We’ve come a long way over the past two years in waking up to the threat posed by the CCP. We’ve begun rebuilding our military, we’ve strengthened safeguards against weaponized foreign investment, and we’re in the middle of a major diplomatic campaign about 5G.

Responding to the CCP’s aggression is not a partisan issue. But it will be a defining issue. Across the free world, politicians left, right, & center will be forced to confront the reality that our democracies are facing their greatest challenge in decades.

To get it out of the way, the CCP leaders overseeing the concentration camps of Xinjiang, where a million or more are being detained largely on account of their religion, are in fact, “bad folks.” But here’s where things get interesting.
Biden has been roundly criticized, and for good reason. But his comments--and the reaction to them--are worth thinking about further.

Yesterday, former VP Biden said that China’s leaders are “not bad folks” and that China does not pose a competitive challenge to the US. This is dangerous thinking, and it’s the logic that led to decades of bipartisan neglect while the CCP worked tirelessly to overtake us.
